current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eOne plausible reason for both the stigma and undertreatment of behavioral health problems is the perception that conditions such as depression are less \u0026ldquo;real\u0026rdquo; than clearly physical ailments, such as a broken leg or liver disease. Many people even suspect that curing a mental illness is largely under the volitional control of those suffering from it. Moreover, the treatment of mental illness is often perceived as being imprecise and relatively ineffective. Therefore, urging companies to take mental health more seriously requires demonstrating both the physiological reality of mental disorders and the possibility of more effective treatment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDepression is a heterogeneous disorder that \u003ca href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.brat.2014.08.008\"\u003emanifests with a variety of symptoms\u003c/a\u003e including \u0026ldquo;sleep disturbance, guilt, loss of energy, impaired concentration, change in appetite . . . and suicidal ideation.\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 1]] This heterogeneity has made diagnoses and evaluations of treatments more difficult. However, recently there has been substantial progress in understanding the physiology of mental health issues. To take one example, major depressive disorder (MDD) in fact \u003cem\u003edoes\u003c/em\u003e have physiological consequences that are evident in neuroimaging studies of the brain. Neuroimaging as a diagnostic tool has the advantage of being \u0026ldquo;a safe, noninvasive procedure that is ideally suited for simultaneously identifying aberrant behavior, brain structure, and brain function.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeanne Williams \u003ca href=\"https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanpsy/article/PIIS2215-0366(15)00579-9/fulltext\"\u003ehas outlined\u003c/a\u003e a \u0026ldquo;neural circuit taxonomy\u0026rdquo; for both depression and anxiety. The fundamental idea is that there are different neurological manifestations\u0026mdash;for instance, in which regions of the brain are active and are connected to one another\u0026mdash;for different manifestations of depression. Such a taxonomy can be used to link symptoms to underlying neural disorders as revealed through neuroimaging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAmidst the COVID-19 crisis, many people are facing the impact of sustained and uncontrollable sources of stress that affect brain physiology. Using her taxonomy, Williams and her colleagues \u003ca href=\"https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bbih.2020.100078\"\u003ehave illustrated how stress and isolation related to COVID-19 may affect different neural archetypes for anxiety and stress\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA taxonomy of different forms of depression makes it possible to associate treatment outcomes with different manifestations of the disease. Such an approach would do for psychiatry what has occurred in other medical domains such as cancer treatment and other diseases over the past 20 years: advancing clinical practice by matching treatments more effectively to each version of the underlying disease. Better understanding the physiological etiology of mental illness can also help move practice toward prevention. Instead of waiting till the equivalent of \u0026ldquo;stage 4\u0026rdquo; of a mental illness, when a person facing a crisis due to the accumulated burden of disability feels that suicide is the only choice, we might be able to detect the problem early, at something like \u0026ldquo;stage 1\u0026rdquo; or before onset of a mental disorder, and treat preemptively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen treatments are matched to different disease archetypes, doctors can prescribe more robust healthcare interventions. As precision psychiatry becomes a more common standard of care, mental health treatments will become even more effective, giving more confidence to those who fund treatment of employee behavioral health conditions, such as depression, that their investment will pay off for both the company and its people.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The promise of precision psychiatry"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eManpreet K.Singh and Ian H.
